docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans today displayed a final version of their bill to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly. They promised to secure approval by the full House in 10 days. Democrats objected, saying the elderly needed more extensive coverage. The plan would cost $350 billion over 10 years. That is far more than the $190 billion that President Bush proposed but much less than the $800 billion plan favored by House Democrats, or $400 billion to $500 billion program proposed by Senate Democrats.

headline.main: House G.O.P. Offers Bill for Drug Payments for the Elderly

docs.abstract: House Republicans offer final version of their bill to provide prescription drug benefits to elderly and promise to secure approval by full House in 10 days; Democrats object, saying elderly need more extensive coverage; plan would cost $350 billion over 10 years, far more than $190 billion Pres Bush proposed but much less than $800 billion plan favored by House Democeats, or $400 billion to $500 billion program proposed by Senate Democrats (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday House Republicans announced their prescription drug plan for retirees. It was, of course, an election-year gesture. So, to be sure, was last week's rival announcement by Senate Democrats. Soon each side will be accusing the other of obstructionism. What's a voter to think? The short answer is that the Senate Democrats have a plan that can be criticized but is definitely workable. The House Republicans, by contrast, have a plan that would quickly turn into a fiasco -- but not, of course, until after the next election.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column says Senate Democrats have prescription drug plan for retirees that can be criticized but is definitely workable, while House Republicans' plan is far less generous and would leave many truly needy retirees behind; says another flaw in Republican plan is that it would subsidize insurance companies to provide drug coverage instead of providing insurance directly; debunks theory that competiton among private insurance providers would somehow lead to lower costs; suspects that Republicans do not want any drug plan to pass, and that retired Americans will not be getting prescription drug coverage under Medicare anytime soon (M)
docs.snippet: Yesterday House Republicans announced their prescription drug plan for retirees. It was, of course, an election-year gesture. So, to be sure, was last week's rival announcement by Senate Democrats. Soon each side will be accusing the other of...

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 200 union members, health care workers and community leaders packed a hearing room here today to debate Westchester County's proposed version of the so-called living-wage laws that several cities around the country have adopted. The Westchester bill would require companies to pay one of the highest minimum wages in the country -- $11.50 an hour with health benefits, or $13 an hour without -- to workers engaged in projects that receive any county money.

headline.main: $11.50-an-Hour Wage Law Debated at Westchester Hearing

docs.abstract: More than 200 union members, health care workers and community leaders pack hearing in White Plains to voice support for Westchester County's proposed version of so-called living-wage laws, which would require companies to pay one of highest minimum wages in country -- $11.50 an hour with health benefits, or $13 an hour without -- to workers engaged in projects that receive any county money; business leaders say legislation would force companies to slash low-paying jobs and would ultimately hurt workers it is designed to help (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the third time this year, employees at three private bus companies in Queens went on strike yesterday, leaving more than 115,000 daily riders scrambling for alternatives and, in some cases, at wits' end. About 1,500 drivers, mechanics and cleaners for Queens Surface Corporation, Jamaica Buses Inc. and Triboro Coach Corporation, which work under contract with the city, participated in the strike yesterday, union officials said. Livery-cab drivers and vans hired by the city stopped along the 42 bus routes affected to pick up stranded passengers. Union officials said last night that the strike, coming after a one-day surprise strike in January and a two-day strike in February, would continue indefinitely.

headline.main: Blaming City, Workers Strike 3 Bus Companies in Queens

docs.abstract: Employees strike three private bus companies that serve more than 115,000 daily riders in Queens under contract with city; Transport Workers Union, Local 100, their union, wants improvements in health benefits and says dispute can be settled only by city, not companies, Queens Surface Corp, Jamaica Buses and Triboro Coach Corp; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Insurance-Squeezed Doctors Fold Their Tents'' (news article, June 13): Malpractice litigators know that it is easy to use patients' suffering to good advantage in the courtroom. A disabled patient in front of a jury draws its sympathy. It is easier for a jury to award a large sum of money than it is to understand the complexity of the case.
docs.abstract: Dr Edward Volpintesta letter on June 13 article holds medical malpractice cases should be tried by mediation without litigators or in 'medical courts' staffed by impartial physician-judges

docs.lead_paragraph: NO matter how you slice it, the trend of returning to the nest after college is not much fun. For four years, you had autonomy, all-night escapades and the chance to run around the world as if you owned it. Then, one June day, your universe collapses like a warped mortarboard. Health insurance disappears. Loans kick in. With no money and no job, you often have no choice but to go home to your parents. I know about this first hand. After receiving a bachelor's degree in communications more than a decade ago, I moved into my parents' home in the Boston suburb where I grew up. Never mind that two years earlier I was hitchhiking my way across Egypt, Israel and Europe and following the Grateful Dead in the United States. Never mind that I'd been living in my own apartment and preparing my own meals. The truth was bitter: I was penniless and jobless, and the country was in a recession.

headline.main: You Earned Your Wings, So Return to the Nest

docs.abstract: Abby Ellin article explores rising trend of college students returning home to parents, penniless and jobless, after graduation; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mary Cary Morrison, the daughter of Mary Myers Hilliard of Oyster Bay Cove, N.Y., and R. Hamilton Morrison Jr. of Hobe Sound, Fla., was married yesterday to Clay Adams Cauthen, a son of Amanda Jane Cauthen and McGregor Cauthen of Signal Mountain, Tenn. The Rev. Diana Mahida-Blum officiated at the Hobe Sound Community Presbyterian Church. Mrs. Cauthen, 31, is known as Cary. She graduated from the University of Virginia. Her father, who is retired, founded Morrison Williams Whittle, an advertising agency that was in Washington; he is now a private restorer of historic buildings in Florida. The bride's stepfather, Landon Hilliard, is a partner in Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, the private bank in New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''THE pharmacist will see you now.'' At the Kerr Drug Store in Chapel Hill, N.C., customers can meet with a specially trained pharmacist who will check their cholesterol and suggest how to maintain acceptable levels. Or they can attend a stop-smoking clinic, take a bone-density test, receive information on diabetes or sign up for a course on women's health issues. (And, yes, they can have their prescriptions filled, too.)

headline.main: Here Are Your Pills. Do You Want the Seminar?

docs.abstract: Small but growing number of drugstores are expanding their services to include broader range of health management services; physicians are guardedly supportive of pharmacists entry into patient care (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Cherished, but for What?'' (Love & Money, June 2) criticized prenuptial agreements, even though our legal system, reflecting socioeconomic trends, has encouraged the use of such agreements for more than two decades now.
docs.abstract: Arlene G Dubin letter disagrees with contentions of June 2 article concerning prenuptual agreements
